description: From Ancient Greek διαλεκτική (dialektikḗ, “the art of argument through interactive questioning and answering”), from διαλεκτικός (dialektikós, “competent debater”), from διαλέγομαι (dialégomai, “to participate in a dialogue”), from διά (diá, “inter, through”) + λέγειν (légein, “to speak”).

entries.meaning: (philosophy, uncountable) A systematic method of argument that attempts to resolve the contradictions in opposing views or ideas.
examples: The dialectics of absolute & relative, concrete & abstract, subject & object, and theory & practice is focused on some of the most important questions in philosophy.
